Summary of amendments/ Record documents superseded by:

Replaces MMP008 The Management of Medication Errors (SUH) and CP/PO/00117 (BTUH). Updated content incorporating NHS just culture guide and updated reflection paperwork and new appendices. Streamlined content covered by Trust Incident policy. New content for learning from incidents. New policy for MEHT

data.text: Contents
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) .................................. 10
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust .................................. 11
Immediate actions following a medication incident .............................................. 15
Introduction

The World Health Organisation launched its third global patient safety challenge, Medication Without Harm, in 2017. The overall goal of the challenge is to improve medication safety by strengthening the systems for reducing avoidable medication- related harm.
What is a medication error?

The National Patient Safety Agency's (NPSA) definition of medication errors is: “Patient safety incidents involving medicines in which there has been an error in the process of prescribing, dispensing, preparing, administering, monitoring, or providing medicine advice, regardless of whether any harm occurred”.

All medicines have inherent hazards. Medicines are often toxic in overdose or have the potential to cause harm if used inappropriately or incorrectly. Usually, medication errors happen because the safeguards and defences intended to prevent medication errors from happening are inadequate or fail.

A medication error can pose a threat to the patient as well as the organisation. It is recognised that it is important to support staff when they have been involved in a medication error/near miss as it can cause distress and concern for practitioners, in particular when there is a direct impact on patients.
Why do medication errors occur?

The administration of a medicine to a patient is the result of several activities by different practitioners and may also be underpinned by organisational policy. Every step in the medicines management process (prescription, dispensing, preparation, administration etc.) has the potential for failure, to varying degrees.

The opportunity for this process to fail is well described in literature using the Swiss cheese model. For example, an unsafe prescription is the problem that gets through one hole in the slice of cheese, but is then challenged by another professional e.g. doctor, allied health professional, nurse or pharmacist (the “defensive layer” of the next slice of cheese).

1.5.1  Systems such as ePrescribing exist as these defensive layers. The system has built-in safety features to reduce or eliminate errors but does not replace professional judgement. For example, the system may help prevent incorrect dosing frequencies but will not identify the appropriateness for the specific patient (e.g. need for dose reduction in renal impairment).
Just Culture
This policy encourages a just culture. This is a culture based upon the principles of fairness, quality, transparency, reporting, learning and safety. Just culture promotes:
An open culture - transparency and discussion, removing fears;
A reporting culture - raising concerns;
A learning culture - learning from mistakes or incidents, and sharing lessons learnt;
Empowerment of professionals - involvement in shared learning and changes to practice;
Safety through an enhanced patient experience and quality of service - reduced likelihood of similar mistakes and incidents happening again.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Strengthen the organisations' just culture in response to adverse medication- related events;
Provide a framework to support members of staff involved in an incident in an individualised manner so that the risk of such errors recurring are minimised as far as possible;
Provide a framework for identifying human and system factors contributing to medication incidents ensuring there is a comprehensive assessment of the context surrounding the incident;
Provide a framework for practitioners to challenge, improve and share best practice, facilitating organisational learning;
Provide a framework to embed learning into everyday practice so that learning for incidents is sustained.
Set out appropriate actions expected by all staff to ensure these are applied consistently across the organisation.

This policy applies to all employees of the Trust, including bank staff and agency staff working in the Trust, who are involved in the prescribing, ordering, supply, administration, storage or disposal of medicines, or are involved in any aspect of medicine usage. This includes pre-registration healthcare professionals (e.g. student nurse/student midwife etc.) and medical students. These staff are required to familiarise themselves with the contents of, and practice within, this policy, its appendices and related documents.
Internal pharmacy dispensing errors

These are incidents which are picked up before leaving the department (near- misses) that are identified as part of the established routine dispensing and accuracy checking processes. The site pharmacy near-miss tool and/or the Prescription Tracking System are utilised to record these. Pharmacy aseptic production errors, which are picked up before leaving the manufacturing unit, are recorded using departmental non-conformance reports, as a regulatory requirement.

These types of error are reported and managed in accordance with pharmacy departmental procedures, and not this document. However, individual and shared learning principles should be applied based on this policy, including reflective practice where appropriate. All pharmacy incidents that leave the department; near- miss or not, are managed in accordance with this document.
Definitions

table_items.text: The process of giving a medicine to a patient
The Trusts' electronic incident reporting systems (site specific)
To assemble and supply a medicine in accordance with a valid order (e.g. prescription). This is principally but not exclusively undertaken by the department of pharmacy.
A physical, mental, emotional or social aspect that is specific to humans and may influence how people interact with the environment and people around them.
The immediate manager for the individual involved in a medication incident (e.g. ward manger, specialist pharmacist, consultant).

The definition of medicine is that used in the Medicines Act 1968 which uses the term ‘medicinal product'. That is, any substance administered for treating, preventing or diagnosing disease, for contraception, for inducing anaesthesia or modifying a normal physiological function. Medical gases are medicinal products. Nutritional supplements via the oral or enteral route are classed as foods. Parenteral nutrition is a medicine.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG) or equivalent
The site multi-professional group which regularly meets to review medication error incident themes, improve reporting and learning and take local action to improve medication safety.

Any adverse healthcare event or omission involving medication during clinical care. This is irrespective of whether such errors lead to adverse consequences or not. This includes all processes including prescribing, dispensing, supply, preparation, administration, monitoring and disposal of medicines.

The nominated specialist who supports local medication error reporting and learning, acts as the main contact for NHS England and MHRA concerning medicines safety and represents the Trust within the National Medication Safety Network and East of England Regional MSO network. They are supported by a medication safety team on each site.
Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency
The process of carrying out routine checks on either the patient or equipment with respect to the administration of medicines to a patient.
The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence
An event or situation that could have resulted in an accident, injury or illness, but through timely intervention did not actually occur
National Patient Safety Agency (closed in 2010, however legacy resources are still applicable)
The process of manipulation of a medicine into a form in which it can be given to a patient

To order the supply of a prescription only medicine for a named patient. (In the extended, commonly-used sense) – to authorise by means of a prescription the supply of any medicine (not just a prescription-only medicine). This may be in writing or in an approved electronic format.

This is the overarching manager for day-to-day management for a professional group within a care area or department. For a Nurse this is the Directorate/ Divisional Matron; For a Pharmacist this is the Clinical Lead Pharmacist; For a Doctor this is the Directorate/ Divisional Governance Lead for Medical Staff.

A medicines-use process where either multiple opportunities for error/s are allowed to progress routinely to the next stage in the process; and/or a critical step in the process allows errors to progress routinely to the next stage in the process. (see section 1.5)

data.text: The following lists examples of scenarios where medication errors can occur. This is not a definitive list, and as such clinicians, managers, and governance managers must exercise professional judgement, requesting advice from senior pharmacists, where appropriate.

table_items.text: Patient prescribed wrong medication / dose /route/ rate / frequency Medication prescribed to wrong patient Transcription errors Prescribing without taking into account the patient's clinical condition Prescribing without taking into account patient clinical parameters (e.g. weight, organ function, allergy status) Prescription not signed Prescription expired without re-prescribing if appropriate to do so Deviation from Trust Policy and Guidelines pertaining to Medicines Management Failure to escalate a concern with any aspect of prescribing of medicines that leads to or potentially may cause harm. Incorrect or omitted VTE prophylaxis in line with VTE assessment

Patient dispensed wrong medication / dose /form Medication dispensed to wrong patient or location Patient dispensed an out-of-date medicine Medication is labelled incorrectly Deviation from Trust Policy and Guidelines pertaining to Medicines Management Failure to escalate a concern with any aspect of medication dispensing process that leads to or potentially may cause harm.
Preparation and Administration Errors examples include:

Patient administered wrong medication / dose /route/ frequency Medication administered to wrong patient Patient administered an out-of-date medicine Medication omitted (especially critical medicines) without a clinical rationale Administration is not documented Medication incorrectly prepared Incorrect infusion rate Medication administered late/early* (* this is a complex issue and the full context of late/early administration should be taken into account. However, if it would have a significant detrimental effect on patient care, this would constitute an incident) Deviation from Trust Policy and Guidelines pertaining to Medicines Management Failure to escalate a concern with any aspect of medication administration process that leads to or potentially may cause harm.

Patient allergic to medication but medication was prescribed and/or dispensed and/or administered Failure to provide the patient with correct information regarding their medication e.g. when to take, what it is for, side effects. Failure to monitor therapeutic levels Failure to monitor administering equipment Failure to monitor patient who is undertaking self-administration Deviation from Trust Policy and Guidelines pertaining to Medicines Management Failure to escalate a concern with any aspect of monitoring of medication use that leads to or potentially may cause harm.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)  Duties Are:
Medicines Optimisation Committee (MOC) (group-wide), or equivalent Responsible for:
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG), or equivalent Responsible for:
Site Directorate / Divisional Governance Groups
Responsible for:
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust Duties Are:
Chief Executive
As the Trust Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for:
Chief Medical Officer
As the nominated group board director for medication safety:
Chief Nursing Officer Responsible for:
national learning.
Site Medical Director
As the nominated site director on each site for medication safety:
Site Director of Nursing
Responsible for:
Group Chief Pharmacist (Director of Pharmacy)
Responsible for:
Controlled Drug Accountable Officer
There is one CDAO for each legal NHS Trust entity:
Deputy Chief Pharmacist (Site Lead)
Responsible for:
Patient Safety Team (or equivalent)
Responsible for:
Medication Safety Officer (MSO) Pharmacist (or nominated site deputy) Responsible for (within their resource):
Site Medication Safety Team Responsible for (within their resource):
Site Directorate/Divisional Pharmacists (or nominated deputy) Responsible for:
nurses/midwives.
Senior Manager (or nominated deputy)
Responsible for:
Line Manager (or nominated deputy)
Responsible for:
All professionally registered and non-registered staff involved with medicines use
Responsible for:
Immediate actions following a medication incident
Regardless of actual patient harm, all necessary steps must immediately be taken to ensure immediate and ongoing patient safety.
If patient HAS taken/ been given the medicine
Patient safety is paramount.

Assess the condition of affected patient/s, observe and monitor for any adverse events and a review of the patient must be undertaken by medical staff as a matter of urgency, dependent on the potential harm.
If medication was provided to the patient and they have taken home, they must be contacted immediately and their condition assessed as above. This may include re-attending the hospital.

The error must be reported immediately to the professional in charge of the clinical area (i.e. nurse/midwife in charge) and the medical team in charge of the care for the patient/s. Out of hours the oncall doctor and out of hours nursing service (if this service exists on the site) must be bleeped
immediately.
If patient has NOT taken/ been given the medicine
In working hours: inform the relevant professional in charge to which the error incident relates.

Out of hours wait until next working day (only if medicine not taken) and contact relevant professional in charge. Remove the medicine to avoid accidental administration at a later date, seeking advice from the out-of- hours team (on call doctor or oncall nurse support team, where exists (site specific).
Expectation when notified of medication error or near miss
Based on clinical assessment/judgement/nature of incident, a clinician may attend to review the patient or give advice.
Where relevant, advice must be sought from a pharmacist and prescriber regarding the possible outcomes of medication error.
Inform the patient as soon as appropriate (see section 6), in line with the Trusts Duty of Candour Policy (or equivalent).
Prescribing Incident

Where incident is due to poor prescribing the prescribing doctor must cancel the incorrect prescription and re-prescribe. If they are unavailable, another doctor from same team / oncall doctor must do this.
Incorrect prescriptions must be made safe immediately to prevent further errors. This may involve other medical staff teams and pharmacists where time is critical.
No administration of this medicine must occur until re-prescribed correctly.
A pharmacist should be contacted for advice where appropriate.
Dispensing errors
A dispensing error may be a hospital pharmacy or community pharmacy error found with patients' own medicines.
Immediately withdraw the medication from use.

Inform the site hospital pharmacy team immediately and make arrangement for re-dispensing, if needed. The dispensary team leader must be informed if the error originated in the hospital pharmacy; they will escalate to Pharmacy Operations Lead as appropriate.
Retain the medication and all packaging to give to pharmacy. This is important for effective investigation to be undertaken by the site or community pharmacy.
No administration of this medicine must occur until re-dispensed correctly.
Medicines Prepared/Administered

The manager should ensure that any implicated medication that may be useful in the investigation is retained (syringes, labels, medication etc.). These details may be important to help identify root causes of the incident.
No administration must occur until device is determined safe beyond doubt (or replacement obtained).
Medical Device
Where the incident involves a problem with a device, this must be notified to the medical equipment team (MEMS – or equivalent service) immediately, and the device removed from service.
All infusion lines, syringes and medication must be bagged within the area for examination, if required.
Monitoring incident
Where there is any concern that the monitoring or interpretation of monitoring of a patient's treatment has been erroneous seek advice immediately from medical and senior medical staff if unsure.
Where the incident is attributed to a resource or skill/knowledge issue this must be reviewed immediately, reassigning staff if deemed necessary.
No further administration must be undertaken until authorised by senior medical staff.
Unaccounted loss of controlled drugs
This must be managed in accordance with the Trust Controlled Drugs Policy.
Important documentation
The nurse/midwife in charge, in conjunction with the most senior medical staff present (if appropriate) should take any necessary copies of charts and obtain statements from the staff involved.
Once the patient is safe, report the incident
Always complete an incident report on the trust incident reporting system.
Always complete an incident report for near-misses, as these provide useful information for improvement and awareness of risks.
Document  the  incident  in  the  patient  healthcare  record,  including  the outcome.
Informing the patient

The organisation acknowledges that when things go wrong, honest and open communication with the patient and/or relatives is fundamental to the ongoing partnership between them, those providing their care, and the organisation.

Following introduction of duty of candour legislation in 2015 the organisation must inform, and apologise, to patients if there have been mistakes in their care that have led, or could have led, to significant harm.
Where moderate severity harm or above has occurred, there are additional legal requirements. This is detailed in MSEPO-19014 Policy for Management of Incidents

The patient (parent/guardian/next of kin) must be informed by nurse in charge (or equivalent), line manager and the doctor in charge of the patient's care at that moment in time. If appropriate an apology should be given and documented, acknowledging that an apology is not an admission of liability.
Staff involved in incidents
Human error is inevitable. A member of staff who has been practising successfully does not suddenly become incompetent or unsafe after a single medication error incident.

However, for an error to occur, an important step in the process would have to be omitted, or not carried out as intended. There is a potential for this to recur if the cause is not identified. It is therefore vital that the line manager and member/s of staff who were involved with the error identify exactly what went wrong and how, and take steps to rectify this.
The line manager must ensure that any immediate remedial action for patient safety is carried out as soon as possible (such as supervised practice, revised duties etc.).
Once the initial facts have been gathered, staff should be invited to undertake reflection (see section 10).

An incident review meeting to discuss their reflective practice and the incident must be undertaken between the line manager and staff member within two weeks (see section 11). This will identify other appropriate actions that may include re-undertaking medication competencies. Where requested these must also be completed within two weeks. It should be noted that prolonged delay in resuming activity could adversely affect the staff member's confidence and practice in their area.

Effective learning from incidents happens in an environment where an individual is comfortable in opening up and being honest about the situation. It is unacceptable for any initial incident management meetings to be framed as a formal reprimand. Only a thorough investigation in line with this document can determine if further action is warranted involving the individual.

Staff welfare must be considered during the error / near miss management / investigation process. Appropriate support must be offered and made available, regardless of the severity of the incident. This may include establishing support from a named ‘buddy' or referral to the occupational health service. Staff support is available from a range of sources and this is given in MSEPO-19014 Policy for Management of Incidents, or from Human Resources.
Recording employees involved in incidents

There is a feature in the incident reporting system to record employees involved in incidents. Line managers should enter the staff member name/s in this specific section only. This information is never sent to the national incident reporting system. The incident reporting system can then be used to run a search of all previous incidents involving the individual, should there be a future concern.
Agency Staff (all professions)

Where agency staff are involved in an error/near miss, the bank office must be notified. They will notify the agency about the error/near miss and be involved in the management of the incident as soon as an error is identified. Where an agency doctor is involved, this includes informing the doctor's responsible officer regarding any serious incidents.
Bank Trust Staff (all professions)

Where bank staff are involved in an error/near miss, the specific bank office manager must also be informed about the error/near miss and be involved in the management of the incident (as per this policy) as soon as an error is identified. They must follow the same process as substantive staff.
Pre-Registration Staff and Medical Students

Where pre-registration students or medical students are involved in an error/near miss the university will need to be informed. The lead education and training professional for each group of pre-registration staff should also be notified.
Minor medication errors
Medication incidents vary considerable in terms of potential for harm, learning opportunity and appropriateness of extensive RCA investigation.

Medication incidents of a minor nature (see below); those where the remedial action is quick, usually limited to one individual and an isolated incident; may be managed without a full reflection and review meeting. It is important to recognise that some minor errors have potential to cause serious harm and these should be dealt with more formally in line with this document. If in doubt, staff should seek advice from a senior / specialist pharmacist.
Persistent or repeated errors
These can be considered as either:
Multiple occasions of the same error type:
OR
Multiple occasions of different medication error type:
These situations are a prompt for a more thorough incident management process. These must involve full reflection with the review meeting identifying key learning activities (See sections 9-11).
Minor errors may include:
Prescribing errors (e.g. poor legibility / failure to print clearly);
Administration errors (e.g. omission of a non-critical medicine stocked on ward);
Dispensing errors (e.g. spelling error on label);
Correctional pharmacist interventions which may be recorded elsewhere.
Minor prescribing errors

Most errors are intercepted before they lead to harm and it is noted that new prescribers may develop a degree of complacency around prescribing. Therefore it is important that these errors are fed back to individual or teams of doctors/ non-medical prescribers on an ad-hoc basis.

Minor prescribing errors where remedial action is performed by the pharmacist may be entered into the incident report as ‘immediate actions', at point of incident report submission. Where this is clearly sufficient to final approve and close the incident, this may be done so with agreement from the pharmacist. The pharmacist should escalate persistent error concerns with the same prescriber to their educational supervisor. Evidence of the errors should exist for this to support learning.

Nurses/midwives can also feed back to doctors in the same way though they are encouraged to escalate prescribing errors to pharmacists to deliver the feedback where they feel unable to, or require further advice as part of the prescriber's learning.

data.url: MSEPO-20206 Management of Learning from Medication Error Incidents.003.png

data.text: Errors can be pointed out to the member of staff, including any advice on how to avoid in future (e.g. signposting to useful guidelines, top tips etc.). The error should be corrected promptly. . Repetitive errors of this kind should be reported to the line manager with consideration of reflection/review undertaken as below.
Persistent or Repeated Errors

Staff who make more than one medication error may require additional training, supervision and support. This could be repeating the same error type (e.g. omission of medicines) or multiple occasions of errors regardless of type of error.
It is important to establish themes with the repeated errors to understand if there is a particular issue with carrying out a process or whether a broader range of concerns apply.

The incident reporting system can be used to run a search of all previous incidents involving the individual, should there be a future concern. Alternatively the staff member's departmental employee record should have copies of previous reflections and incident meetings.
Line managers should reflect on the medication process in which these errors are occurring and keep an open mind as to whether a medication system review is also required (see section 13).
Managers can approach pharmacists and the site medication safety team to support learning and consider requesting staff to undertake medication safety training again where appropriate.

Where repeated errors occur despite training and support, it is likely that the line manager will need to consider more formal actions. This will be in line with the Trust Disciplinary Policy or Trust Capability Policy (or equivalents).
Reflection for staff involved in a medication error incident
Written reflections are a useful tool to help the member of staff and line manager identify what went wrong, how and why. This is also a useful source of information during the investigation.

The purpose of preparing a reflective account is developmental and not punitive; however, this documentation may be referred to as evidence of previous support/action/learning should repeat errors of the same or similar nature occur.
Reflections should be undertaken as soon as possible after the event and be submitted to the line manger within 5 working days.

Reflections should be undertaken for all incidents, however it is recognised that this may be of limited value in some cases. As such, it is the line manager's discretion to request a reflection, except in defined situations (see below).
It is expected that written reflections are always undertaken for incidents where any of the following apply:
Medication reaches the patient, or care area involved (e.g. ward);
Patient harm severity is risk scored moderate, high or extreme;
Involves an actual or near-miss Never Event incident;

Member of staff has been involved in more than one medication incident in the past two months or more than two in the past six months. This information can be checked in the staff member's department-held HR folder, or using the incident reporting system (see section 7.8)

All staff involved in a medication error incident; regardless of grade, professional registration or not, is expected to reflect on the event. This should be documented using the multidisciplinary incident reflection record (appendix 1).

Where staff are struggling with the reflection process, this should be treated sensitively and reference to the fishbone root causes tool may be useful (see appendices 7 and 8). Staff should be invited to review their reflection if there are any deficiencies or unanswered sections which may be useful to the investigation.
Doctors should include a copy of the reflection in their appraisal portfolio.
Medication Incident Review Meetings

An incident review meeting is one carried out between the staff member and manager. It is influenced by the severity of harm (or potential risk of harm) and the extent to which the individual has been involved previously in any other error incidents or near misses.
Utilise the NHS Just Culture Guide as a structure for the conversation. A record of the review is documented using appendix 2.
The investigation activities and discussion must cover the following:

Identification and agreement of the root cause factors. Consult the medication error incident RCA checklists / fishbone (appendices 3-8) to ensure all root causes are identified and the main root cause/s are established;
Determine any staff support required and agree this;
Determine knowledge gaps with respect to policy, procedure or accepted practice needs;
Identify learning opportunities for the individual;
Determine the safe-to-practice status of the individual;
Identify learning within the team and consider where to involve the site medication safety team for wider learning.

It must be clear who is responsible for taking what actions, and in what timescale. An action plan must be completed on the incident review record. Where actions are identified for others, these must be agreed before finalising to ensure they are realistic and achievable.
Following the investigation, a copy of the incident reflection record and review record should be placed in the local employee record within the department.
These records demonstrate effective management and support has taken place; and that effective professional development and learning has been identified and facilitated.

This record may be removed after a defined time, if deemed appropriate by the senior manager. This record should be reviewed in line with the Trust appraisal process confirming positive change has occurred.

A copy of the reflection is generally not submitted to the staff member's human resources record unless recommended by a senior manager (i.e. in cases where escalated via the disciplinary or capability policies).

The electronic incident report should be updated and completed in line with the Trust Incident Policy (or equivalent policies) and training given by the respective site. This should state clearly what learning has taken place.
Human Factors Analysis

Human factors analysis explores how staff relate to the situation around them; the environment, the people around them, their capabilities and limitations. Identifying these factors can be used to improve performance and safety.
Solutions to human factors in medication errors
This may include the following:

Training individuals – to better prepare them for work/ conditions and situations, such as being ‘busy'. This may involve strategies to ensure they remain safe in a situation where it is continuously very busy (e.g. ways of checking medicines before prescribing dispensing, administering);

Environmental design – can this be improved where medicines are prescribed, dispensed, prepared and administered. This can include how we reduce the risk mis-selections (e.g. look-alike drugs) from the shelf, reduce distractions, and if the work space allows the individual to concentrate.
Equipment design – tools and automation, therefore exploring if the ePrescribing system (where used) can be optimised or whether something can be automated where currently is manually undertaken.

Task design – changing what staff do rather than just the device they use. This could be assigning tasks to other workers/professionals or to automate the process (e.g. ePrescribing, electronic ordering of medicines, robotic dispensing etc.)
Weak Medication Systems Review
Systemic / Organisational Factors

In the event that a clear systemic or organisational factor is identified, the consultant, matron, and medication safety team (including MSO) should be consulted without delay. They will evaluate the best way to manage this, which may include escalation at the site MOSG (or equivalent) and MOC.

Changes in practice may be required alongside learning which is co-ordinated by the site MOSG and the medication safety team. This may involve other stakeholders in the organisation. These may include:
System changes (e.g. implementing changes to procedural documents, and actual system in practice)
Elimination of the risk (e.g. change medication, stop medication reaching patient permanently)
Optimising systems (e.g. ePrescribing)
Revised teaching sessions and eLearning for medicines safety.
Suitability of policy / procedures / accepted practice

The incident may identify a problem with the documented process for how a task is carried out. This may be how it is interpreted (i.e. wrongly leading to error or differences in practice), omissions in the documented process, or an identified need for a documented process.
It is important to recognise that implementing changes to documents in itself does not prevent errors. It may be that improved signposting to existing resources is required instead.
Safe-to-Practice Status

Upon undertaking the root cause analysis the line manager may feel it is appropriate to review the duties of the member of staff (i.e. suspension) until a critical incident reflective exercise is undertaken.

There may be occasions where the employee wishes to stop themselves from continuing a specific duty. This should be respected and addressed within the medication incident review. There must be sound rationale documented for this with clear actions to determine when that person can return to those duties, where appropriate.
Supervised practice:

Supervised practice can provide assurance that staff who made the error is following correct procedures. The method and length of supervised practice will depend primarily on the severity of the error and/or potential for harm.
Other factors to consider include:
availability of support staff to supervise;
insight of the member of staff as detailed in their reflective account;
circumstances surrounding the medication error,
confidence of the member of staff;
any previous incidents raising concern (e.g. themes).

The method and length of supervised practice should ideally be decided in partnership between the line manager and staff who made the medication error. At the end of the supervised practice both parties must be confident that the member of staff has changed his/her practice so that the likelihood of future medication error is minimal.
Role of the Medication Safety Officer (MSO) Pharmacist
This role is a requirement of the NHS England Patient Safety Alert - Stage Three: Directive Improving medication error incident reporting and learning.

The MSO is integral to improving medication error incident reporting and learning within the Trust. One of the MSOs' key roles is to promote the safe use of medicines across their organisations and be the main experts in this area.

The MSO serves as the essential link between the identification and implementation of (local and national) medication safety initiatives and the daily operations to improve patient safety with the use of medicines.
The MSO operates within the allocated resource and their role with respect to improving the quality of incident coding reporting is detailed in appendix 9.
The Patient Safety Domain at NHS England/NHS Improvement and the MHRA support the MSO in the form of the National Medication Safety Network.

MSOs attend conferences/workshops, regular online WebEx and network meetings, email discussion groups and online information forums to discuss topics identified at local and national level. These include the identification of new risks and best practice to minimise these risks, implementing patient safety guidance and improving incident reporting quality and learning.
Incident Themes, Trends and Shared Learning
Learning from errors and near misses must be shared across all services.
The medication safety team, based in pharmacy, identifies any themes and trends within errors / near miss incidents (see appendix 9).
Theme analysis details:
Incident numbers;
Incident type & breakdown by drug or system processes;
Where and comparables (e.g. to other sites, where possible);
New or emerging themes and identified root causes (e.g. new process etc.).

Theme analysis is provided to directorates/divisions quarterly via their nominated pharmacist. Themes can be by type (e.g. omission, wrong dose etc.) and by drug. Focus with drug themes is with high-risk drugs identified through the medication safety officer network.
Directorates will be expected to engage with the pharmacy team in terms of identifying actions and how to manage the situation to drive safety improvement.
Shared learning is delivered in the following ways:
Regular medication safety bulletins (MedSafety Focus / MedAlerts)
Pharmacist cascading of mini-teaching to ward-based teams e.g. messages of the day/week
Pharmacist 1:1 junior doctor teaching at ward level
Induction training and directorate-specific medicine safety sessions to medical staff
Safety initiatives such as ‘Medication Safety Week'

Site MOSG focuses on the key incident themes and specific risk reduction strategies. These will form recommendations that are taken to relevant governance groups for approval. Where appropriate, arrangements may be made for policies, guidelines and procedures to be developed or amended.

Concerns where learning is not happening or is ineffective will be escalated by exception reporting via the group Medicines Optimisation Committee to the Host Patient Safety Group. (refer to appendix 9).
Shared learning applicable to the Clinical Commissioning Group and/or GPs will be disseminated via the group Medicines Optimisation Committee.
Training Requirements
Personnel involved in managing staff will be trained to ensure they understand and follow risk management procedures. The site corporate governance team should be contacted for staff new to the role.

The site medication safety team, based in the pharmacy directorate, and the MSO can provide advice and support on how to manage and share the learning from medication incidents. The clinical pharmacy team is also available for general advice and support.
Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG) Pharmacy Board Governance
Directorate/Division Governance Group Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Directorate/ Divisional Pharmacist Head Nurse Medical Staff Governance Lead

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This policy has been reviewed and approved by the Medicines Optimisation Committee, overseen by pharmacy, across the MSE group of hospitals. This will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust intranet. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the site Medication Safety Team within the department of pharmacy.
References
Black Country Partnership NHS Foundation Trust (2015). Medication Errors Policy.
General Medical Council (2013). Good practice in prescribing and managing medicines and devices.
General Pharmaceutical Council. (2017). Standards for pharmacy professionals.
Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust (2017). Medication Error Policy. Lincolnshire Community Health Services NHS Trust (2018). Management of Medication Errors Policy.

National Patient Safety Agency (2009). Being open: communicating patient safety incidents with patients, their families and carers. Patient Safety Alert. [online] Available at https://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090218151701/http://www.npsa.n hs.uk/nrls/improvingpatientsafety/patient-safety-tools-and-guidance/beingopen/ [Accessed 01/05/2019].

National Patient Safety Agency (2004). Root Cause Analysis (RCA) Toolkit NHS England (2014); NHS/PSA/D/2014/005 – Patient Safety Alert - Stage Three: Directive Improving medication error incident reporting and learning NHS England (2014); NHS/PSA/D/2014/005 – Patient Safety Alert - Stage Three: Directive Improving medication error incident reporting and learning Supporting Information
NHS Improvement (2018). A just culture guide [online] Available at https://improvement.nhs.uk/resources/just-culture-guide/ [Accessed 09/12/2019].
Nursing and Midwifery Council. (2018).The code: Professional standards of practice and behaviour for nurses, midwives and nursing associates.

Royal College of Physicians (2017). Supporting junior doctors in safe prescribing [online] Available at https://www.rcplondon.ac.uk/projects/outputs/supporting-junior-doctors-safe- prescribing  [Accessed 09/12/2019].

Royal Pharmaceutical Society (2018). Professional guidance on the Safe and Secure Handling of Medicines. [online] Available at: https://www.rpharms.com/recognition/setting-professional-standards/safe-and- secure-handling-of-medicines/professional-guidance-on-the-safe-and-secure- handling-of-medicines [Accessed 09/12/2019].
Equality Impact Assessment
This policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment. The output of the assessment demonstrates that no one as a consequence of this policy is placed at a disadvantage over others.

Appendix 2: Multidisciplinary Medication Incident Reflection Record

table_items.text: You may find the ‘FISHBONE' diagram in policy MSBPO MM 19XXX helpful with your
Tell us briefly about the incident (max 1-2 sentences)
Tell us your thoughts on any agreed Trust protocols/procedures & accepted practice
related to this incident. (Do they exist? One needed? Is it clear? Is it achievable? Are they right? If not,
What information did you and could you have used to influence your decisions/actions?
(Think about your professional code/standards or expected standard of practice)
Thinking back on the incident what were your feelings at the time and compared to now?
What was trying to be achieved?
What factors may have influenced you (or the team) with respect to this incident?
(E.g., work based, home based, your physical / mental health, environment working in etc.)
Tell us what you learnt and what good emerged from the incident to improve your practice and
How will you prevent this incident happening again (what could we do differently?)
How would you like this learning shared?
Comments from discussion with your line manager:

Reflection has been read, reviewed, comments added and signed by line manager.
Discuss and agree (between line manager and individual) what are the main root causes.
(This should involve use of the reflective practice, fishbone / RCA checklists in Medication Incident
Please summarise outcomes, and comment where needed

a) Is a referral to staff support services needed? Practice/Educational Facilitator Occupational Health Other (please state): b) Has there been a breach of policy/procedure/accepted practice? Yes (if so, discuss with Medication Safety Team in pharmacy via line manager) d) Has any specific training / learning need been identified? Yes (state in action plan) No (state reason why here):
Please confirm safe-to-practice status for individual

YES – safe to practice unsupervised YES – safe to practice with 1:1 supervision NO - (please state reason): For no, reassessment of competency is likely (state in action plan, e.g. workbook / eLearning)
Specific Action to address learning need
Please ensure you update the incident report to ensure consistency in documentation
